title: Can AI make a Crayon drawing?
text:
A growing TikTok trend has emerged, where creators are giving AI some of their pictures and asking it to recreate the image in a crayon drawing. I found this interesting, since people are quick to criticize the use of AI for creating art, but this trend has escaped this criticism. Today, I gave AI one of my favorite pictures‚Äìmy brother, cousins, and myself with my grandparents‚Äìto see if AI could recreate the image using a crayon-based art style.
Here is how my conversation with ChatGBT went:
Create a whimsical crayon drawing based on this picture loose, wobbly lines and exaggerated shapes. Use a cartoon drawing stye so the image looks like a drawing from crayon. Use waxy textures on white paper and keep the background simple and childlike.

ChatGBT responded with this picture:

This was an interesting response. It is easy to tell that this ‚Äúdrawing‚Äù was not completed by a child, and the coloring in the drawing does not look natural; the strokes look the same, giving the drawing a digital look. The arms and noses are also weird. However, I am impressed by ChatGPT‚Äôs ability to create new drawings in the background. the cloud, sun, and fence were not in the original picture; rather, ChatGPT created it.

title: Can I make me laugh?
text:
I asked ChatGBT is if it can tell me a joke, because I wanted to test to see if AI can make me laugh. I was curious to see if AI is creative enough to tell jokes.
Here is how my conversation with ChatGBT went:
Tell me a joke to make me laugh
Sure thing‚Äîhere‚Äôs one for you:
Why don‚Äôt graveyards ever get overcrowded?
Because people are dying to get in. ü™¶üòÖ
Want me to go darker, more clever, or just plain silly with the next one?
Do a plain silly one
Alright, here‚Äôs a plain silly one:
Why can‚Äôt you trust stairs?
Because they‚Äôre always up to something! üòÜ
Want me to throw in a punny one next?

This conversation was very interesting, even though it was minimal. I was shocked to see how ChatGPT used dark humor and joked about cemeteries. I also thought the interaction would be more similar to a conversation, where ChatGPT would give me a chance to answer the initial question instead of immediately telling me the answer. It felt like ChatGPT was simply giving me an example of a joke, instead of interacting with me. I also found it interesting how ChatGPT used emojis. It made the interaction seem friendly and even silly, which matches the prompt of asking for a joke. Finally, ChatGPT told me it can provide me with different jokes of different genres, which kept me engaged with AI longer than I expected. Overall, though, I did not find the jokes funny, so it failed in making me laugh.

title: Can AI solve NYT Games?
text:
I try to play the New York Times game every so often, but I struggle with playing the game Connections, where you group words together based on your guessed category. Connections has also gone viral on social media, with people discussing how challenging the game can become. This inspired me to see if artificial intelligence can think critically enough to help me solve Connections.
This is how my conversation with ChatGPT went:
Can you help me solve today‚Äôs connection puzzle

Nice puzzle ‚Äî got it!
Group 1 ‚Äî things with a shell EGG, SNAIL, HARD TACO, M&M (eggshell, snail shell, taco shell, candy shell)
Group 2 ‚Äî types of dog BULL, WATCH, UNDER, LAP (bulldog, watchdog, underdog, lapdog)
Group 3 ‚Äî words meaning finished COMPLETE, DONE, OVER, THROUGH
Group 4 ‚Äî ways to drink quickly / take a drink SLUG, GULP, BELT, SHOT
Want me to explain any of the connections in more detail?
I then entered these answer choices into the puzzle to determine if they were correct. They were!

This was an interesting interaction with ChatGPT. The LLM did not explain its thinking behind the answer choices, which is what I was initially looking for. I wanted the interaction to be more based on hints and clues, rather than just the answers. I wanted AI to help me solve the puzzle instead of just solving it for me. It was also interesting to see the order in which AI solved the puzzle. Most people try to find the categories in the order of yellow, green, blue, and then purple, since that is the order of difficulty. So, it was interesting to see AI correctly guess the hardest category on its second answer choice.

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: AI and Legos
text:
After my recent blog post where I had ChatGPT turn my family portrait into a crayon drawing, I was curious to see what other creative designs AI can replicate. As a big fan of Lego, I asked ChatGPT to create a Lego minifigure based on a picture of myself.
Here is how my conversation with ChatGBT went:
Turn me into a Lego minifigure

ChatGBT responded with this picture:

This was a fun prompt for AI. It prompts me to think about whether Lego engineers and designers are going to begin using AI to create their products. I also begin to wonder if some Lego designers have their jobs in jeopardy due to AI‚Äôs ability to turn pictures into Lego designs. The picture that ChatGPT gave me was fairly accurate. ChatGPT even went the extra mile and turned the boat in the picture into Legos, too. Something inaccurate about the photo AI gave me is that the right sleeve color should be tan, not green. However, ChatGPT gave an impressive recreation of the photo into Lego, furthering the debate and fear about AI‚Äôs role in creative design and art.
